I got it with the lens and am very pleased with it in general.For a relative noob like myself, the camera has fully automatic modes and a variety of 'semi-automatic' shooting modes. They cover practically every common scenario you might shoot with. There's also full manual for those who know a bit more, which I admittedly don't. However straight out of the box it's very easy to use this camera- there's on-screen directions for the settings and the button and dial design is intuitive. In a place that doesn't need flash? There's a no flash preset. Subject is moving fast? Sport mode. It's really hard to screw this up, and although it might not be quite as good as properly configured manual, it's really not bad.The camera shoots about 3 FPS, which is more than I usually need. It has a wide range of ISO settings and can take pictures well in moonlit darkness (though for this, you probably want a tripod as the exposure time is long). The optics are excellent as is to be expected, and autofocus is generally very quick. There are times if set to fully automatic mode that it can take a while to adjust- especially if the target is small or close. I find it's sometimes better to use quick focus settings if you think you might miss something. The flash automatically pops up when engaged and works decently well. If you want a bigger unit, there's a mount for it.Build quality in general is solid, and though heavier and bulkier than a 4/3 camera or point and shoot, it's not by any means unwieldy. It is clearly designed for right handed shooters though, as practically all the controls are on that side. The lenses are interchangeable, but the stock lens is a very good all-rounder. It might not have the craziest zoom, but so far I've found it works perfectly in most shooting situations. Battery life on this camera is fantastic despite the fact the battery pack is pretty small. It charges very fast via the (included) cradle and spares are cheap if you really want one. The camera supports SDXC up to 64GB, and at native 12.2 MP this is enough space for over 10,000 shots- more than I could possibly do in any given week (or probably even year). If you stick to the viewfinder it can easily last a full day on one charge.The controls include dials for quick settings, adjustments, and standard buttons for reviewing content and navigating menus. It also has a dedicated flash button, though this is often disabled in presets. The shutter button is a light press to focus, hard press to shoot- and generally very responsive. Image quality is superb in all conditions- you can definitely get some 'wow' impact from this, and I've had many friends comment on how good the stills are. I haven't tried shooting video with this, and probably never will- it's just not the purpose I got it for. On that note, the autofocus motor and camera click are quite loud. This is perhaps the only quibble I have with this camera, but it's not a huge issue for me. The camera has a very fast startup time- for all intents and purposes it's ready to go when you flip the switch.I'll acknowledge this is probably not the best DSLR out there in terms of feature set and sensor quality, but it's darn good for what you pay for it and is easy to use for neophytes. It's actually cheaper than many 4/3 cameras and about the same weight (though it is bulkier). I personally prefer the viewfinder, though my wife prefers shooting with the LCD. Either way, it works very well and can shoot often enough, fast enough, and for long enough that it's really hard to miss any photo-op. The EOS Rebel T3 meets all my criteria and I am very pleased with it overall.

Reviews.Title: Great bang for your buck
Reviews.Author: Steven K. Baker "KellRazor"
Reviews.Content: What's to say that hasn't been said? Yes, costs were cut making a budget EOS Camera for the "every man". Thank you Canon for reaching out and up in design and thinking. All the gripes people have about this camera crack me up. It's a great beginner, but suits the seasoned photographer as well. I read where someone called it "plasticky"... people complained that it didn't shoot video in standard def... if you change lenses, it will shoot in standard, for the record.I put a grip on mine, bought some old vintage lenses, threw on some filters and a tulip hood... upgraded the memory card... and after shooting up about 3 cards full of photos as well as 3 full of film since Christmas, I gotta think the world is filled with a bunch of malcontents.Sure... there are gobs and gobs of better more expensive camera's out there, but if this thing came out 10 years ago it would be the most amazing cutting edge tool on the market today. Don't let any bad, picky reviews fool you. This thing is pure Canon soul. I LOVE MINE!!!

Reviews.Title: Great First Time Camera!
Reviews.Author: TonyD
Reviews.Content: With the hope and enthusiasm of getting into the world of photography, I was looking for a great introductory level DSLR camera that I could get my hands on. After everything I read it came down to being between Nikon D3100 and the Canon EOS T3. In the end, the majority came to the conclusion that though the T3 was cheaper in build quality than the Nikon, the Canon T3 took overall better pictures. And in the end what sealed this deal was the $449 purchase price with no tax and shipping through Amazon; Amazing! Anyways, I've now had the camera for a few weeks, and absolutely love it! One of the best features, and what makes it great for a novice photographer is the guide feature that comes with this camera, which can be turned on or off. Basically what it does is describe what each and every function of the camera does from the P, Tv, Av, M settings to the little manual adjusted functions such as exposure, shutter speed, and aperture. This along with some simple reading has allowed me to learn the basic ins and outs of using an SLR camera rather quickly. I still have a long, long way to go, but I know with this camera every step of the way will be extremely enjoyable.

Reviews.Title: Must have for families with kids!
Reviews.Author: Laura
Reviews.Content: I wanted a camera that would literally allow me to capture "a moment in time".  I purchased it when my baby was 2 months old, frustrated with my small digital camera that would get the picture AFTER our baby quit smiling.  We have owned this camera for over 2 months and it has not let us down!  The shutter speed is very quick, and you can take multiple pictures quickly.  It's durable, lightweight, and takes excellent pictures.  Best yet, the price is very competitive--not to mention the money we've saved by not having to hire a professional photographer each month!!

Reviews.Title: Keeps getting better...
Reviews.Author: Stephen
Reviews.Content: This is my first DSLR camera.  I have shopped and shopped looking for one and even asked friends and professional photographers.  The end result is purchasing the Canon T3.  I have been slowly trying all the features and I am just amazed of the picture quality and ease of use.  This has been a great choice.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Danell L. Manchee
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera for almost a week and I LOVE IT!  This is my first DSLR camera and I decided to go with a Canon because my point and shoot camera is a Canon and so I felt that I was already familiar with the menu and dial systems.  I have been very happy with this purchase.I purchased this camera to take pictures of my family and our vacations. It's easy to use right out of the box.  The presets are fantastic but am also looking forward to learning all the features that are available on this camera.  The only negative I've found so far it that the camera can get heavy when wearing around my neck for an extended period of time.  I many need to find another solution for carrying it around.But the bottom line is that I'm very pleased with this camera.  It is all that I wanted it to be.

Reviews.Title: So far.....REALLY GOOD
Reviews.Author: Ed
Reviews.Content: Bought the T3 a month ago for a trip to Yellowston Nat'l Park and the Grand Tetons and I'm totally impressed with this camera!!  It's my first DSLR and I and very satisfied with the product, I'm still learning and playing with the exposures and the features.  It is very easy to navigate the features and menus, great portability........I love it!!  I would definetly recommend this to a friend!

Reviews.Title: Fantastic entry level DSLR
Reviews.Author: ej719
Reviews.Content: I'll admit my bias right away, I LOVE Canons. They perform consistently, have the widest selection of compatible and affordable after-market lenses and accessories, and have a very user-friendly button layout and menu interface. I've shot on film SLR's and G-series, as well as an Olympus micro four thirds camera, but never a DSLR. I had always held out, thinking they were over my head or too pricey for just a hobbyist, but I'm glad I finally made the leap.This is a solid device with every possible feature that an average hobbyist-intermediate photog would ever use. If you never take it out of Auto you may be disappointed, it's not going to do the work of composition and lighting for you and make you dinner afterward. But once you turn that dial to one of the manual or semi-manual modes you will open up a world of possibilities.Some complaints I've read so far: Feels cheap. Well, no, not once the battery and lenses are attached. It has a nice weight to it, a little front-heavy with a longer lens but otherwise balanced.Slow to focus: yeah, it is. But manual focus is soooo much faster and fun to use once you get the hang of it. You may never auto-focus again.Slow fps: True, there are faster continuous shooters out there but not without stepping up a few hundred dollars in price. If you're shooting sports or other action on a primary basis you may want to invest in something a little quicker.The thing about DSLR's is that you really only need a basic body. If you're going to invest money, invest it in your lenses. When you upgrade bodies, if you stay with the same brand or mount type (or get an adapter) you can continue to use your favorite lenses. This is a great body to start with. This camera, plus the 50mm 1.8 lens, may be all you ever need.I love this camera. It takes absolutely gorgeous photographs, it's a pleasure to use, and Canon hasn't changed their lens mount in a zillion years so I can use all my old 35mm SLR lenses and flash. I don't feel like I've sold my soul for it, and it will really grow with me as I hone my skill.

Reviews.Title: Love it so far
Reviews.Author: C. Brackett "TMCMOM3"
Reviews.Content: I bought this, knowing it was an entry level. Having only minimal knowledge of photography, I didnt want to spend a ton of money, and I wanted something I could handle. After doing a ton of research and talking to mom and pop photo shops (they always seem to know and understand more than the people at like Best Buy or Fry's) and professional photographer friends, I settled on this one. I am so in love. I find myself constantly taking pictures. I have spent tons of time reading and watching tutorials on how to use the camera and have learned SO much. Pictures I have taken 2 weeks ago are horrible compared to the ones I take now, after understanding what to do, what settings to use and what ISO vs shutter speed etc mean. I am looking at getting additional lenses, but I think my T3 and I are going to be buds for a long time! So happy with it!My only qualm is there is not additional battery pack support with this model.

Reviews.Title: Canon Digital Rebel T3
Reviews.Author: D. Irving
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for Astro photography and regular photography.Much more sensitive to low light than my Olympus E-410 and less noise atlow light conditions. Auto mode works well indoors but in lower light conditionsit pops the flash up and washes out the background. Landscape works better at twilight conditions.Battery life seems to be good, but am ordering a 2000mah battery for a spare.Shutter speed only goes down to 30" but with Aputure Timer Camera Remote Control Shutter that is no problem.Recommend this camera!

Reviews.Title: A handy tool for an amateur in photography
Reviews.Author: Guiyuan Li
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera on last Thanksgiving and have been using it on every trip since then. Overall, I am very satisfied with this product. It gives me a lot to freedom in modes such as aperture/shutter priority and manual exposure, and the photos it take are way much better than that of the point-and-shot I used to have. This camera (plus the Canon Digital Photo Professional software that came free in box ) meets all my current needs as an amateur in photography while saving me money for extra lenses(I got 55-250mm zoom lens and 50mm f1.8 prime lens). I am very happy with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the new or hobby photographer
Reviews.Author: Manderpants
Reviews.Content: I have always loved to take pictures. I received my first SLR camera, a Canon Rebel G2, when I was teenager and experimented with that for a while but never really took it past that. Many years later with the birth of my first child, I decided I really wanted to actively pursue photography as a hobby. After a few weeks of researching DSLR's I decided this was the one for me. It struck the ideal balance between features and price and seems to be a great camera for me to grow with. Sure, there might not be as many features as the T3i or T2i but for the price I really can't ask for a better camera.The camera feels very light which could explain why many refer to the "cheap" build quality in their reviews. However, there is nothing wrong with the build quality. With the right settings the pictures I have taken come out crisp and clear with a generally nice white balance. The menus, buttons, and dial are simple and easy to navigate through. The camera is easy enough for someone who is not familiar with DSLR's to take great photos using the preset modes. My husband took some lovely outdoor pictures of me and my son using the "Portrait" preset. The burst shooting is pretty good when shooting in JPEG (~3 fps) but slows down noticeably in RAW and fills the buffer after just a few shots. This hasn't really been an issue for me yet, though down the road it could prove problematic.The cons for me include not having a rubberized grip and the indoor white balance issue. As someone who is rather clumsy at times I would prefer to have a rubberized grip to help me keep a better grip on my camera but to overcome this I have resorted to just using my camera strap. The white balance is generally good but I have noticed that when shooting in low lighting there tends to be a rather annoying orange cast to the photos even when changing the white balance settings. This is easily overcome with some post-processing tweaks though.There are small issues, most notably with the indoor low-light white balance, but they are easily worked around. For me, the kit lens leaves a lot to be desired. I recently picked up the Canon EF 50mm f/1.8 II Camera Lens and I was not disappointed. My photos went from nice to "Wow! You took that?" I would highly recommend getting the Canon EF 50mm f/1.8 II lens with this camera.Overall, the Rebel T3 is a very nice entry-level DSLR capable of producing fantastic results for those looking to get started with DSLR photography and are on a budget.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Camera for the Price!
Reviews.Author: Charles Hanson
Reviews.Content: This is such a wonderful camera! It is my first DSLR, and I am so happy with the purchase. Not only is it easy to pick up on the controls, but it is fun to use! The pictures turn out very crisp, and the kit lens is great!I am in love with photography now, and simply cannot get enough of taking pictures with my new Canon T3. You won't be disappointed with your purchase. This camera has a lot of potential.

Reviews.Title: Great first DSLR
Reviews.Author: F. Malik
Reviews.Content: I love this camera, it's my first DSLR.  The quality of the pictures are excellent, the speed at which pictures are taken is excellent.  Very pleased.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding Deal
Reviews.Author: W. Rudge
Reviews.Content: I must admit that the overall deal I received on this Canon EOS Rebel T3 kit was better than expected. The package deal with a Canon EF-S 55-250mm lens saved me over $200.00. The has operated flawlessly since charging. This camera is worth the price.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera with minor flaws
Reviews.Author: B. Donley
Reviews.Content: I'm new to the DSLR game so I can't tell you that this camera is better than one that's more expensive, but I will tell you, it takes awesome pictures when you get the settings right,I shoot in full auto mode along with manual to make sure I at-least get one good shot.This camera is definitively better than a point and shoot, I compared an image shot with the T3 and a image shot with a Canon Powershot 120is and the images were much better.The only thing I don't like about the camera is it doesn't have 1080p and you can't adjust most settings when you're in video mode which for me is a big let down.However I didn't buy the camera for the video I bought it to take pictures and it does that pretty well if you know how to use the manual settings. If you get things wrong there's always Adobe lightroom providing the images aren't to far gone.The view finder for me is a little bit on the small side and viewing the information in the view finder is difficult for me to view sometimes.I don't like how the battery and sd card slot are on the bottom, it makes it a pain when using a tripod. If you're card is full and you're using a tripod you have to unscrew it from the tripod and then take it out which sucks.The menu is semi informative for the noob shooter like me, when  you go into manual mode and you go to adjust a setting it tells you that if you increase a value or decrease a value what it will do for the picture.It comes with a 18-55mm kit lens,its ok for what it is just don't expect to zoom out very far the image quality with it is ok there's a little noise out low light levels but can be tweaked in adobe lightroom the good thing is that this camera is compatible with the full line of Canon EF and EF-S lenses so that's good.Overall despite the minor flaws this camera has I would recommend it for the person that doesn't have the cash to step up to the T3I personally I would of stepped up to the T3I if I had the money but at the time I didn't but i'm perfectly happy with this model, it takes great pictures and that's all I can really ask for so yes id recommend people to buy this camera.

Reviews.Title: great entry-level dslr, at a killer price
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Keeping it simple - this is our first dslr, but view it as a stepping stone for sometime in the future. Comparing this against even the used options on craigslist, the price was just too hard to pass up ($510, amazon prime). The best used alternative would've been a similar entry-level, 2-5 years old, with two lenses if it was at the older end. Getting a new camera, with zero shutter actuations and a new battery was worthwhile, mainly because we knew we'd be hooked on dslr's once we got one. We had such good results with previous canon point-and-shoots, that we opted to go for the T3 over a Nikon D3100, despite the apparent disadvantages in specs. It's just so darn user-friendly, I can't imagine anything being easier, but I will say we are somewhat biased (I keep saying "we" - my wife and I are photo nerds, but mostly amateur, and between off-roading and outdoor adventures, to artsy photo creations, to indoor action with two young kids, we kinda cover a large range of "users"). After a short time with this camera, I won't go into the details as many others have. It just works well, and it's easy. Even better is that it's as helpful as you want it to be - very tunable in terms of auto functions and helpful hints, but easily removed if you gain experience and don't want to be babied. Seems to be an awesome, affordable intro to dslr tech.

Reviews.Title: A Great Starter Camera
Reviews.Author: Thomas M
Reviews.Content: Being the photography editor for my collegiate newspaper, I'm always on the lookout for great camera, lens, and gear deals for the upcoming year. At the start of the new semester, I saw this on sale and knew it would be a great fit for our newsroom.PROS:It's really light. I'm used to hauling around big camera bodies with heavy lenses (ex. Canon 300mm f2.8 L). So when I tried this camera out for the first time, it was a little surprising. However, for someone not used to the world of DSLR's, this is a great starting weight. Light and compact, it still feels great in my hands. I have yet to have a complaint by any of my staff on its handling as well.Image quality. I was expecting image quality on this to be not as good due to its price. However, after using it in the field for the past 6 months, it's stood up to all of our other cameras in this area. Great color reproduction and color accuracy. This is actually our go to camera when we do last minute portraits of people in the newsroom. We have yet to have a bad performance from this guy.There's no fancy stuff. It's sort of weird to say this, but it is nice to use this camera once in a blue moon. Most cameras these days have so many features that sometimes the photography itself gets overshadowed. With this camera, it's bare bones basic, which means just you and picture. In a way, it's a good test on how good of a photographer you really are. Get a great picture on this camera and you can get a great picture on any camera.CONS:It's really light. This is also a bad thing. Being a collegiate newsroom, we have some high quality glass, which, more often than not, tends to be heavy. As a result, the weight distribution tends to be off. Now, most people buying this camera won't be using L series primes and f2.8 zoom lenses. However, it is something to be aware of.The screen. To be blunt, it's pretty bad. It's actually so laughably low-resolution that you can see the individual pixels. However, it does do its purpose. Colors are accurate and the screen has decent angles. This also makes the Live View function moot. Yes, you could use it. However, without a decent screen, Live View becomes a super low-res version of your final product. Despite this being aimed at first time users, I really do wish Canon put a more high-resolution screen on this. Being able to see a picture on a high-res screen just makes common sense. Not a deal breaker, but a missed opportunity.OVERALL:Just to make a point, I shot an entire NCAA Men's Soccer game on this camera. Was it wise to do that? No. It only has 3 frames per second, its ISO tops out at a usable 3200, and it's not weather resistant at any level. Are these qualities I look for in a newsroom worthy camera? Not really. However, it is a great starter camera for new photogs. My new staff members are out and about taking newspaper quality photos that's easy to use and learn on. The same can be said of the soccer game. When I showed the pictures I took to a staff member, he couldn't believe I used the T3. That's the point of this camera. It has just enough to instill the confidence in a user so that they'll get the shot. Your pictures won't be blurry, they won't be insanely dark, and they'll be cropped just right. Since buying this camera for our newsroom, I've recommended this camera to 2 photogs who have bought, and used, this camera to great success. I'll be looking forward to adding 2-3 more for our newsroom.

Reviews.Title: Love!
Reviews.Author: Angela E
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love having this as my back up camera it is so light weight and perfect for our family outings!!!

Reviews.Title: FIRST DSLR - COMING FROM POINT & SHOOT & SMARTPHONES
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This is my first DSLR. My photography needs are just wanting to shoot quality pictures of my family in everyday life, holidays, & special events like graduation. My experience with digital photography over the past 10 years is Fuji Finepix A200, GE A730, 2 Sony Cybershots (not sure of the models), Fuji Finepix F900EXR, Fuji S8200, Samsung Galaxy S II, & Samsung Galaxy Note II (yes the latter two are not technically cameras but since many use their smartphones for point & shoots I will include them).I wish I would've made the move to dslr sooner. This is only an entry-level & the image quality compared to point & shoots is amazing.Autofocus using the viewfinder is immediate (if looking for this on a p&s; check out the Fuji Finepix F900EXR). Using the LCD screen, autofocus is slower, but I am beginning to understand the benefits of the viewfinder. I can definitely see the benefits of manual focus but not very good at it yet. I'll keep practicing.Colors turn out true to what I see with my eye. There is a lot of detail in each image. Possibly the term for the images I'm getting is "true to life".Images are noise free, atleast to my untrained eye. My main problem with newer p&s; cameras is the level of noise & grain in the pictures. I think it has something to do with the high megapixels crammed into a tiny sensor, b/c my first digital camera did not produce that much noise, & it was only 3 megapixels (Fuji Finepix A200). The sensor was even slightly smaller at 1/2.7" compared to the typical 1/2.3" sensor in most p&s; today.I am only using full auto mode right now, but I am slowly reading through the entire manual to hopefully learn some things to take even better pictures. But if the pictures never get any better than they are in full auto mode, I will still be pleased having this level of image quality to preserve family memories.I was concerned about not taking as many pictures, b/c it would require toting a large camera around, & I am used to the convenience of p&s; and smartphones. But I bought the smallest bag that would fit my dslr with lens attached. It also holds the charger & usb cord, but that's not necessary. I carry the bag on my shoulder along with my purse, so it's not a problem.I was also concerned about the issue I hear about dust on the sensor. But for now, I'm using the lens that came with the camera & don't plan on changing lenses in the near future (although the Tamron 18-270mm looks interesting & seems it would give the zoom flexibility you get w/point & shoots w/o changing lenses), so I keep the lens attached. From what I understand, this should minimize dust entry into the camera. *Experienced DSLR users, correct me if I'm wrong.*Video was not a must, but I do like having all-in-one for photo & video. It's 720p instead of 1080p. It does not have continual autofocus. I took a short test home video, & this did not seem to be a problem for home videos. I'm not sure about recording a child's school program or something like that.It looks like the Nikon D3100 might be the better entry-level option, atleast looking at specs. It has the auto sensor dust cleaning, 1080p video, & full time video autofocus. It's slightly more expensive, and this Canon was really the most I could spend on a camera.I'm sure I have a lot to learn, but coming from a point & shoot, you will not be dissapointed, if for no other reason than image quality.

Reviews.Title: Good value
Reviews.Author: Supreme Commander
Reviews.Content: Good camera. Plenty of features with reasonably good ergonomics. I would prefer to have a dedicated depth of field preview button instead of having to assign the function to the select button on the back of the camera. When wearing gloves, it's easy to hit one of the settings buttons that surround the select button.The kit lens has good performance, but is frustrating to use for precise manual focusing. There's just too much slop in the focus ring.

Reviews.Title: Great starter camera
Reviews.Author: Charles Timko
Reviews.Content: To start, I am an amateur at photography.  I have been using cameras on and off for years, my first was a 32mm that belonged to my parents.  I prefer the quality of the photos that SLRs make as opposed to the point-n-clicks.  That said, to the camera.  The build is quite solid, but I don't recommend dropping it.  I did set it down a little rough and it was fine.  The quality of the pictures is perfect for me.  The lens it comes with is perfect for portraits and I wouldn't recommend it for anything else.  The flash is quite good, but I rarely use it as my hand is steady enough for some fantastic pictures without the light.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: KerRAWR
Reviews.Content: This camera is absolutely amazing! My boyfriend has the T4i and although that has some pretty interesting features, I can't help but to love this baby more. I went to a hockey game the other night and even though we sat pretty far away the pictures that I took with this came out excellent! I find this camera to be more lightweight than the Nikon 3100 (I used to rent out my University's camera) and easier to use as well. But that's just my opinion! I'm a Canon girl through and through.Also, comparing it still to the 3100, I find the T3 has sharper, brighter colors especially when you toy around with the "Creative Auto" setting and change up some of the settings there. I believe the grip for the 3100 was rubberized and I will admit that it does take a little adjusting to for the non-rubberized grip, but now after using it for almost two months it's just something natural to me and whenever I use my boyfriend's T4i, the rubberized grip just feels weird to me now! The battery life, for me and how I use it, is excellent! I even left the switch "on" for a whole weekend by accident after taking pictures all day, and picked it right back up and continued to shoot more pictures. I've only had to charge it two or three times so far, and I tend to take at least 20 to 30 pictures a day at the very least. Some days I'll take up to 300 or more!This camera was the best purchase I've made, and I am not disappointed one bit by the performance, the body, and the picture quality!

Reviews.Title: An excellent entry level DSLR
Reviews.Author: Seth T. Vuletich "sv"
Reviews.Content: This camera is likely more than the casual user needs, in fact I think even some professional photographers could do most everything they need to with this camera. About a year and a half ago I saw this camera with the kit lens, a Canon EF 75-300mm f/4-5.6 III Telephoto Zoom Lens for Canon SLR Cameras, a Canon EF-S 55-250mm f/4.0-5.6 IS II Telephoto Zoom Lens for Canon Digital SLR Cameras, a Canon Mark II Inkjet Photo Printer PIXMA Pro9000, and a couple of tiffen filters for around $550 after some rebates. I was looking into cameras, and this deal was too good to pass up, so I made first entry into the DSLR market. I have been very impressed with the camera, it takes over 300 pictures on its battery, has good low light performance, and there are a bunch of generic accessories available for the photographer on a budget.The camera itself feels a little unsubstantial. I have held super zoom cameras that seem more sturdy, and the grip is slippery. The auto-focus is also a little slow. These are really only cosmetic issues, sure the body is plastic and not magnesium, thus it has less resistance to the elements, but that will be the case for any camera under a thousand dollars. The sensor works well and there are more adjustments available than you will likely know what to do with.While 12.2 MP seems low it is not really a bad thing to have fewer pixels on an entry level camera. Although pixel technology in sensors have decreased in size incredibly rapidly, the sensors themselves have not improved proportionally. This means that as the number of pixels increase, the amount of light received per pixel decreases and can result in less vibrant images, although they may be more detailed. 12.2 MP is also just not that low of a pixel count. A 1080p HDTV has only 2 MP, and a movie theater has about 8 MP. I think that you'll find 12.2 MP more than adequate.While this camera takes fine pictures, its video performance could be better. The video is limited to a resolution of 720p and 30fps, additionally it has no input for an external microphone. As such this is not the camera for the video enthusiast. the 5d and 7d are some of the best options for video, in fact they have been used in feature films such as The Avengers and Black Swan, However those cameras cost several times as much as this one, so a video shooting option is nice.The screen is fine, It has a fairly high pixel density and is large enough to do see the interface in decent detail. Where this camera and all cameras like it excel is in the ability to zoom into an area on the screen in live view mode and fine tune the focus to razor sharpness.Overall I'm happy with this camera, it takes beautiful pictures, and is a pretty good bargain. While this camera lacks the features of its more expensive siblings, it has more than enough options to satisfy the casual photographer, and might even make a nice backup for the professional. This makes a good first DSLR, and in the very least allows for the amateur to experiment without the costs associated with film.

Reviews.Title: Canon camera
Reviews.Author: John Calland
Reviews.Content: Super SLR camera that is very easy to use and creates wonderful pictures.  I really dislike trying to use the screen on most compact cameras and this modestly priced camera allows through the lens viewing.  I suggest buying an instruction book because the manual is pretty light on the capabilities of this fine camera.

Reviews.Title: A great dslr for me
Reviews.Author: David R. Hawkins
Reviews.Content: I have been a shutterbug for a longtime.I had a slr film camera with many accessories. Along came digital, so sold the camera and jumped into the digital era with the purchase of many compacts. I wanted more control(m,a,s,iso) so after research and knowing Canon this was my joice.  I am very happy with the purchase and am have fun with the various Modes.Would highly endorse this model for anyone as an entry level dslr.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for the Price.
Reviews.Author: Fursty
Reviews.Content: Overall I am very, very satisfied with my Canon T3. I would recommend this camera to anyone looking to get into DSLR photography.The only small complaints I have...1. Viewfinder and LCD screen are a bit on the small side. It is fine for a while, but after a full day of shooting, I find it does become noticeable.2. Camera mode- Very long distance on the dial between the manual modes and the movie mode. Makes spur of the moment movies a little more challenging without missing the beginning of what is going on. I am pleased with the movie quality though.  Put on a lens in manual focus and shallow depth of field and it is quite pleasing.3.  Biggest regret- Wish I got the body only and got a 17-50mm f/2.8 in place of the kit lens.  The kit lens certainly isn't horrible.  I have just come to find that after using my other lenses, it just really lacks low light functionality and seems to really lack the "pop" that my other lenses have.  I find the images just look uninspiring no matter how well composed.  The images are sharp.  My complaint is more so based on color and contrast.  Obviously not having a larger aperture is a big part of the issue.Other than these few points, I can't say anything bad about this camera.  In fact, if I had to purchase a second body, I would be very likely to get another T3.  There are obviously much better cameras out there, but bang for the buck, this thing is pretty darn good.

Reviews.Title: This is all you need in a DSLR
Reviews.Author: MEJazz
Reviews.Content: First thing to get out of the way is that if you need a DSLR mainly for photography (not videography) then you can't go wrong with this one. The thing that will make any difference in your photos/results is NOT the camera body; its your skills/vision/compositions AND the lenses you have. Save money on body, buy this cheaper unit and use your saving to buy a second lens (the 50mm f1.8 is a MUST HAVE).Now onto why i really like this camera:1. Obviously the price! Espacially when paying more does not get you much more. This is espacially true for people who are looking for their first DSLR. These camera and their accessories WILL get expensive. As i said, the camera body is where you can cut some corners without impacting your end-results much. Buying it during holidays saves you more with deals and packages floating around.2. Battery life: My first DSLR was a Rebel XSi. It was very good but the best part was battery life - outstanding! Later i upgraded to T1i and sold my XSi. The T1i offers higher resolution LCD screen BUT that also causes the battery to drain much faster. This T3 is infact sort of a clone of XSi - same resolution, same kind of LCD and yes, same great battery life!3. Light weight: Its also very light and won't cause any trouble even after a whole day of shooting/wearing this on your neck. If you pair it with a light-weight prime lens like 50mm 1.8 or 35mm 2.0 (i would highly recommend both) - the whole package becomes a light-weight amazing photos machine.4. Easy to use: Perfect for beginners and offers much room to grow/get serious with your stuff. If you are coming from a point-and-shoot, it can act like one where you don't have to worry about any settings at all.This is my 2nd body along with my T1i - notice that i did not call it a "backup camera" - it is infact one of my primary camera. I grab either one depending on which one has the lens mounted that i need at the moment.Final note: I was a Canon-guy and Canon was first to bring the affordable DSLR to market so i went with their product. If you are just starting, it might be worth looking at Nikon D3100 as i've heard that is a better entry-level camera. But if you already have a collection of Canon lenses (or like them more), this is your camera.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Mike C "Mike"
Reviews.Content: I did a ton of research in buying this camera for my wife for a gift.  She loves it.  She is taking photography classes with it right now.  It takes great pictures in the basic auto mode but has a ton of other features once you learn them.  She hasn't used much of the video features so I can't comment on them.  Her initial main use was trying to capture photographs of our children which we could never get with a point and shoot since they are too fast.  It works great for that but has so many other features she has now become more interested in photography.  Overall, great camera for a great price.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding Camera for the Price
Reviews.Author: S. Fairchild
Reviews.Content: The various other reviews highlight the benefits of this camera, so I won't repeat them all. I will just say that I agree this is an great camera for the price. I recently took a picture of my daughter from 10 feet away using an inexpensive 50mm lens. It was possible to zoom in on her eye in the photo and see me sitting on the floor taking the picture (granted it was quite pixelated at that zoom level, but still...). The settings on the camera are also easier to use than those on my old 12.2 MP Canon point and shoot. I am really happy with how the movies turn out as well.The one and only drawback I have found with this camera is that the auto focus is VERY slow when using the LCD to frame a shot. For this reason, I only use the viewfinder now when taking pictures. I get the impression that the LCD view is designed mostly for making movies and not for picture taking.

Reviews.Title: Love it.
Reviews.Author: W. Gardner
Reviews.Content: We are 1 month into having this camera and bought right before the holiday season.  We absolutley love it.  This is our first DSLR and I am extremely happy.  We bought because we had very good experience with Canons in the past.  The camera is very intutive and easy to use.  With the video was higher quality but its very watchable. Overall this thing is great.

Reviews.Title: Canon Rebel- Great for Beginners
Reviews.Author: Niki "Niki"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera about a month ago and it is really great. I am a beginner, and I use it for blog pictures. I think this is a great base camera to start off with and will really help anyone understand how a DSLR works. Takes amazing photos, can't wait to buy a zoom lens.

Reviews.Title: Great Results and Easy to Use
Reviews.Author: Eric J. Koenig
Reviews.Content: I have used Point and Shoot Cameras my entire life. I was intimidated about taking the next step to Digital SLR.  I received this camera in the mail and i was able to use it an hour later for a photo shoot. It has exceeded my expectations in terms of picture quality and the speed, which is incredible.  There are so many options on this camera that every situation of photography is present. I will never go back to point and shoots after having this camera, although i would recommend buying another lens for long range shooting.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic beginner DSLR
Reviews.Author: T. Lee
Reviews.Content: I barely started to get into the DSLR cameras, and I didn't know which one to start. Then after a long research of the DSLR cameras, I came across this model, the Canon EOS Rebel T3. And to be honest, I bought this camera from reading the OTHER reviews, and everyone had stated the same statements that I'm making right now, which is saying that Canon Rebel T3 is a great starter for those people who are starting to get into DSLR cameras. I won't go too much into detail because those are already stated under the description and product overview, but I will say that it's got basic shooting settings, such as close-up, sports mode, portrait mode, regular full shot, etc.For those who are wondering if this camera can record videos: it CAN record videos but it is NOT HD. It's your average quality and I'd compare it to that of a camcorder. It still does record quite well; the video quality is great for a camera that is only meant for picture usage. the built-in sound recorder captures pretty well sounds, without sounding too fuzzy and static-like.As for the lens, it's the standard 18-55mm, which isn't bad. But after awhile, you'll be craving for other better lens, which are just as expensive as the camera, if not more. That is the only "downer", I guess you can call it.All in all, it's a great starter camera and if you are looking for a cheap but great(for what it is) DSLR camera, this one is perfect for you.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera!!!
Reviews.Author: M. Lynne "Margie"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera days before our big trip to Yellowstone National Park.  I had a Cannon G6 but was looking for a new camera that would take amzazing pictures.  Based on other reviews on Amazon I got this camera and it did not dissapoint!!  This camera takes incredible pictures and I couln't have picked a better time to upgrade.  I have gotten so many compliments on my pictures since purchasing it.  Buy this camera, you will be glad you did!!!

Reviews.Title: Amazing Camera!!
Reviews.Author: david
Reviews.Content: For the price of this camera and the features it offers, I am in love. Just received the camera yesterday and I haven't stopped taking pictures yet. Great features, great picture quality and its so easy to use. Even with just the lens it comes with, the macro is amazing. I would recommend this camera to anyone just wanting to buy their first SLR camera.

Reviews.Title: Great first DSLR
Reviews.Author: Sikander
Reviews.Content: Now, just want to say that this is my very first DSLR, but I absolutely love it. It was actually pretty easy to ease right out of the box. Very first thing I did was charge the battery fully and just went crazy with it for the next hour. Most of the shooting modes I had figure out pretty quickly. Putting it on full auto is very helpfull if you just don't feel like manually focussing the lens or turning on the flash and so on. Picture quality is awesome and same for the video. Video was actually one of the main reasons that I chose this SLR over others, because I wanted to get the 75-300mm lens as well. I looked at the Nikon D3100, D3000, the Canon Rebel EOS, the 10 MP models, but for the price and camera features, I found this to be the better deal for me. Going from a point and shoot to this SLR was a smooth transition, I still have my nikon L100, which has awesome image stabilization for video and pics, and the T3's VR is also damn good when using the stock lens that comes with it. But if you record video with the 75-300mm lens, the video will be shaky unless you use tripod or have a very steady hand. Using SD and SDHC cards is also a great convenience, the neck strap is pretty comfortable. I'm still going through the different settings for the modes to get the best picture possible. I would definitely recommend this camera to anyone who is looking for a DSLR.

Reviews.Title: Great gift
Reviews.Author: Linda Monroe
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera for our daughter as she graduated college.  She had expressed an interest in photography for several years and this camera was recommended by my brother in law who is a photographer.  She loved it and is using it every day.  It is easy to use as a beginner and she's already starting to play with the advanced features.  It takes great pictures.  We are very pleased with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: Beginner but Thrilled
Reviews.Author: Az Garcia Family "Az Garcia Family"
Reviews.Content: Ok,so I bought this camera because I was not liking the results of any other point and shoot camera I previously purchased to capture photos of my kids. (5 and 3) Both of them REFUSE to stand still or look at me to be photographed. For the last year I have been using my iPhone which of course does not have flash, and subsequently, I could not take pics in poorly lit environments. So I finally shelled out for this camera.This is day 1, but so far I LOVE IT! I have taken hundreds of just random shots so far of them running and jumping, ignoring me, making faces, photos of the dog, and even pictures of my husband being a clown.I don't know much about the "technicalities" but as a beginner, this camera is easy to use and captures beautiful shots!

Reviews.Title: Couldn't be happier, this thing is awesome!
Reviews.Author: Joe K.
Reviews.Content: We did research through Consumer Reports prior to purchasing, and this camera came highly recommended.  After using it for a month now, I can verify that it is well worth the purchase.  For the value (cheaper than the T3i, T2i, T1, and T1i), I don't notice any drop in quality.  The pictures are phenomenal, and anyone who's used a simple digital camera in the past will have no problem figuring this one out.  Easily one of our best family purchases in years.  I strongly recommend the T3.

Reviews.Title: the Honeymoon is NOT over yet!
Reviews.Author: C. Scanlon "least helpful reviewer"
Reviews.Content: okay, so I admit it; I am an idiot. Just ask my fans on amazon.I was using the Canon EOS Rebel T2i 18 MP CMOS APS-C Digital SLR Camera with 3.0-Inch LCD and EF-S 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 IS Lens all over Ciudad Juarez for over a year and over ten thousand shots, and we were getting real intuitive with one another and all, and I don't know, maybe it was leaving the battery recharging all night on the surging power sources here (should I throw a voltage regulator in the overnight sack and forget the extra underwear?) or what, but after each shot I would have to flick the switch over and over in order to get her going again, like pumping gas in the old Detroit built automobile until it was flooded again. That got old quick, and it quit in the middle of a couple of projects folks wanted done and I would have to lean on this switch CPR to bring her back to life for just one more shot. Got old fast.So, like instead of upgrading to the Canon EOS 7D 18 MP CMOS Digital SLR Camera with 3-inch LCD and 28-135mm f/3.5-5.6 IS USM Standard Zoom Lens, which really remains at 18MP, I had to grab whatver was on the shelf NOW and found this, the T3.Okay, so like I am confused too, over many tihngs, but how come the T2i was 18 MP, and the T3 does not have MORE, you know? Instead the T3 goes DOWN to 12MPbut you know what? For ordinary everyday use and most applications even, nobody will notice the difference.I am still learning to find out where the buttons are now. The review button is in a MORE intuitive spot, but I am not used to that. The Display button is also more easily hit, but I am loving this. It is a lot like running a strpiped back, more convenient T2i, but with fewer buttons and better placed. The center circular buttons around the SET button are ones you will actually use, including ISO, but remember to hit the SET button to activiate the new setting! What I really like is being able to reporgram the Flash button conventiently placed on the tiop near the flash, to ISO, because I am always swapping out into other ISO's. Of course you could do ISO fully Auto up to 6400 (which is the highest ISO on this camera, with no 12800 "H" setting) but Auto, what's that? Trust it?And the excellent (what is it, nine?) nine(?) point Automatic focus system is easily reset to the one point you really want to focus on, but ALWAYS remember to set it back, or to the next point you need focus on. How many shots have we lost that way!? Oh. You, none? Me, well, never mind.Yeah, honeymoon's still. For the kind of guerrilla street shooting I do in Ciudad Juarez, this is a great camera, and all I have to worry about are my own fears. Ok, so, can I take a picture of the cops roughing up that guy, or not? Cops make me nervous; I don't know why. I'd much rather do the cute kitties and burros. Anyway, you can see like three thousand of my shots of Ciudad Juarez over on flickr.com which includes the information as to what camera I am using on the individual photo pages (just click on one of the shots on the photostream page). Also figure that anything uploaded today (right now in fact) May 21, 2011, and later is with the T3.It's really in the lens after all. Get the best lens you can. I am using the Canon EF-S 55-250mm f/4.0-5.6 IS Telephoto Zoom Lens for Canon Digital SLR Cameras but wow, I think prices have dropped here!Have fun and may you always have good light to write with.And, you know, overcome you fears; just get in there and get the shot already.

Reviews.Title: If you want the best first DSLR and best value for the money, buy this camera now!
Reviews.Author: OldPhotoGuy
Reviews.Content: I actually bought the Canon T3 with standard 18-55mm kit lens about two years ago when it was fairly new, and I was torn between this camera and the Nikon D3100 or it's new replacement at the time, the Nikon D3200. Most of the camera publication reviewers were on the fence, not wanting to clearly pick one over the other, the old Canon VS Nikon fight at it's best. This was a big decision for me since my camera taste often exceeds my limited budget, especially now that I'm retired. So not wanting to make a bad investment, I actually tested all 3 cameras and concluded the following: All 3 took great pics, though I slightly favored the color on the Nikon out of the box over the Canon. But the Canon had a much smoother zoom mechanism on the lens and just felt better in my large hands. I also felt the video was better on Canon and easier to use and faster to autofocus. Video was equally important for me as I often switch between the two when shooting my young grandchildren. Considering that I could buy the Canon for $50-$100 less than the Nikons depending on where I bought them,and the fact that all my old EOS Canon lenses from old Canon Rebel XS film SLR would fit the Canon, the choice was ultimately a no brainer. Two years later, my decision has fared me well. Not only have I accumulated two years of fantastic pics that blow away the pictures from my excellent Panasonic Lumix ZS15 pocket point-n-shoot camera , as well as my next stage Panasonic Lumix FZ35 bridge camera (both very highly rated cameras of their type), but thousands of sales by Amazon have verified my enthusiastic recommendation as the Canon T3 is their #1 Best Selling DSLR as of this November 2013 writing. The Nikon D3200 is #3 and the Nikon D3100 is #7 in the Top 10 Amazon Best Sellers list. Another Canon is #2 by the way, which speaks well of the brand, but the arguments of Nikon VS Canon will always continue on a model by model basis. Speaking of that, over the past few years,  both Canon and Nikon have released several new models, each slightly more expensive with slightly more bells and whistles since releasing this entry level model, yet the T3 contiues to dominate sales of all DSLRs on Amazon, not just entry level. You just can't get more proof than that. If you don't believe my opinion, just look at the sales record as it speaks volumes for itself. Incidentally, I discovered a VIVID COLOR setting on the Canon T3, so I was able to match the color that I liked slightly better on the Nikon, so that is no longer an issue.So is the Canon T3 really perfect, worthy of 5 stars? Well, not totally, but there was no way to mark 4.5 stars. My one complaint is that a simple but key feature that Canon puts on almost all of their point and shoot cameras, the quick-shift decicated movie button, is missing from this camera. When I want to switch from stills to movie, as I often do, I have to remove the camera from my eye (I never shoot stills live view off the LCD screen, only movies), view the top selector wheel, and turn it to the movie icon which is as far away as you can get. You lose a lot of time switching over, which means you probably missed that ideal movie of your baby or toddler or pet. Such an easy fix, just a dumb design flaw in my opinion. Also, I don't believe you can shoot a still while simultaneously taking the movie without a hiccup in the movie, as I recall. But this inconvenience is not enough for me to send you to a competing camera as the resulting movie is excellent, even when shown right off the card or copied onto a flash drive inserted in the USB outlet of a 60 inch HDTV. I shoot @ 720p even though 1080p is available as my desktop PC likes downloading and dealing with this HD format better and the quality of the movie is still excellent.Looking ahead, am I so happy that I won't be buying another or upgraded DSLR? Nope. I am a self-admitted camera addict, have been since age 11, so I'm always panting at the new and forthcoming models and dying to try them. I've heard so many rave reviews about the new Nikon D5300 to be released this month (Nov. 2013) that I'm currently saving for one. I've always wanted to own at least one Nikon as I've been a Canon guy forever because it was always the highest rated camera of the type I was buying, but this Nikon D5300 is several steps up with many improvements so I think I'll love it. However, the Nikon D5300 is also about $1200, $800 for the body and $400 for a 18-105mm telephoto lens as I don't want another 18-55mm kit lens like I already have on the Canon. I often wish I could get a little closer and the 105mm should do it.By the way, speaking of lenses, everything you heard about the super value and super performance of the Canon fixed 50mm/1.8 lens is true! I bought one for portraits to get that beautiful background blurr and excellent close-up focus on the subject, and I couldn't be happier. Well worth another $115 or so and great for low-light shots, too.Well, that's my story, two years later with the Canon T3, and I'm sticking to it! I'm also sticking with my trusty "old" Canon T3 until I can afford $1200 to step up and see if all the hype and talk and fuss is true on the Nikon D5300. If it isn't signifcantly better than my Canon T3, I will definitely return it, as I always want my money's worth and there's no sense in replacing a sure winner.

Reviews.Title: Poor Optical Viewfinder
Reviews.Author: Great Faulkner's Ghost
Reviews.Content: I am not completely happy with this camera, despite the excellent quality of the lens and image quality. I bought an SLR instead of a point and shoot because I wanted to 'see through lens' exactly what I was going to get in the picture. That is what SLRs have always been about for me - what you see is what you get. Not on this camera, nor on most digital SLRs under $1000, I discovered to my dismay. You get roughly 95% of the image, which seems like a lot, but is enough to partly defeat the purpose of owning an SLR. For example, in a portrait shot, where you align the top of the frame about an inch or two above the subjects head, you get this huge area above the head instead -- like maybe 18 inches. So instead, to compensate, you have to guess how much to bring the camera down, which risks cutting off more than you want. Sure, you can just shoot it wider angle and crop it later with adobe, but that's a pain, and I don't want to do my composing in the darkroom. My best work is done in the moment, when I take the photo.  Maybe this does not bother most people, but if you are like me and moved to an slr to get away from the slowness and inaccuracy of point and shoot LCD composition, this camera only gets you part of the way there. It is fast, but what you see is not exactly what you get.

Reviews.Title: Love this Camera
Reviews.Author: Josh
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera.  I would definitely recommend it for anyone who is serious about photography.  If you don't know much about photography, aperture, shutter speed, etc, this is too much camera for you.  You'll just end up spending a lot more money to use the same "auto" feature that you would be using on a less expensive camera.  However, if you are a photographer or aspiring to be, this is a great camera with a lot of cool features.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera. Moving up in price gets better $value$
Reviews.Author: Andi C Bair
Reviews.Content: Canon EOS Rebel T3 is an entry-level DSLR camera. More 'DSLR' than 'entry level'. Let me use my usual disclaimer, and admit that with so many good cameras around, it is more about what mix of traits or features you are looking for.On that note, the camera's trait mix is as follows. It is a DSLR with 12.2 resolution (megapixels). Probably the most important point for this class of cameras is the sensor size, which is APS-C. That's just one step below 35mm Full frame.It has an optical viewfinder, which works through a pentaprism. That is the classical SLR construction. You are using the properties of light to view the subject before and during the shot. The purists would argue this is the way it was supposed to be- that is, with minimal electronic intervention. The ISO rating is 6,400 which makes it work better in low light. This rating is below many other DSLRs, but you would hardly ever need a higher ISO. Really. The video is a HD- that is 1080x720 resolution. The camera gives you the option to control the exposure  manually. It does have an external flash option. You would need that for portraits, at least. The LCD screen is a slightly smaller 2.7 inch with 230,000 resolution. The sustainable burst rate- for fast action- is 3 frames per second. The camera also does RAW processing which is useful if you did not want to be limited by JPEG storage only. The camera body weighs 495 grams, which is light compared to DSLRs.The T3 lacks a self-cleaning sensor unit for dust. For all interchangeable lens cameras, dust removal has become an issue, because you only need a speck to spoil the picture. And unless you remove it, it tends to stay inside.A nice camera, but somewhat dated when it comes to some traits.

Reviews.Title: Good beginner camera
Reviews.Author: James Boylen "jimmy boylen"
Reviews.Content: I got this camera because I wanted something better then my phone. It works great for basic shooting and is very light. Great for beginners or students. Overall 4-5

Reviews.Title: Canon Rebel
Reviews.Author: Captric
Reviews.Content: Bought this for work and it does the trick. I am not a professional photographer so don't need all the bells and whistles just plain good photos. It is very fast compared to my other compact camera.

Reviews.Title: What a great deal?!?! (although maybe not for full-time professionals)
Reviews.Author: Insomniac
Reviews.Content: If you're average Joe - Amateur status, this is the perfect DSLR for you. I'm sure that professionals would trash it, and talk about how cheap the lens is, but this camera does EVERYTHING I need it for and more. I would have never guessed I could get a DSLR this nice for $335. Judging by the pictures/results I have gotten with this thing I'd think it was a $800-$1000 camera. I highly recommend this, and I'm glad I didn't waste hundreds of dollars buying a more expensive model.

Reviews.Title: Sweet camera
Reviews.Author: sassafrass66
Reviews.Content: Even though it is a much better camera than the one I own, I purchased this for my 20 year old son, as a combination holiday and birthday present. I'm not sure who was more delighted; him, playing with it and shooting pictures for days on end, or me just observing his pleasure and joy. Canon rules, that's that.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding Camera Technology
Reviews.Author: Robert C. Ladousier "Cajun"
Reviews.Content: I have wanted to get and EOS Digital SLR camera and I feel that I have a good quality product. It has been easy to learn the features and operation of this camera. I am excited about taking pictures of excellent quality of my children and grandchildren.

Reviews.Title: GREAT pictures
Reviews.Author: Amy R. Zirjacks
Reviews.Content: seriously pro-quality, obviously megapixels isn't all that matters, we have no idea what we are doing and end up with really great pictures most of the time, only reason it's not five stars is the bulky-ness of it, I wish it were easier to take along, oh well.  I'm so glad we have it!

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: sk
Reviews.Content: I didn't really see why a nice camera was necessary and kept just buying cheap ones.  Once I compared the quality of the pictures I can't believe we didn't get a nice one sooner.

Reviews.Title: The price is right
Reviews.Author: Charles Coffey "Decorah Lion"
Reviews.Content: I received this camera from Amazon in early January 2013. Since then I have shot nearly 4000 photos with it. Are there better cameras? Of course there are but they cost a lot more money. With regard to the quality of photos, I doubt you would be able to actually see the difference between this and a much more expensive camera unless you made an enlargement over 20 X 30 inches.I owned a Minolta SLR, completely manual, from around 1975 till I traded it in for my first digital camera around the late 1990s. I should have kept the SLR longer but I jumped into digital too early and the first camera was expensive and really not very good. My second digital camera was about the same money but much better. The Rebel T3 has met and exceeded my expectations. I truly enjoy every aspect of using it.Really the first thing I noticed was how well this camera fit my hands. I have about average man sized hands and the fit was excellent. This camera is lighter than my nearly 40 year old Minolta because the T3 is made of plastic. Being lighter is a good thing. I don't think the camera looks or feels cheap. One of my friends, when he first saw the camera, thought I must have spent a fortune on it. I like to get all the bang for my buck I can get and that was the principle reason I bought the T3.The rebel T3 does everything I needed a DSLR to do and does it well. When I bought it, I knew it could only shot about 3 shots a second and some cameras can shoot more. I haven't found this to be much of a loss. 3 shots a second is adequate. It doesn't have a built in GPS. My son has this on his Sony camera and says it takes time to locate itself and really doesn't work as advertised. That might have been a feature I would have liked.This camera can take excellent photos up to 6400 ISO. Considering my background in SLR cameras, where the film you used set the ISO and only went to about 800, 6400 allows me to shot in really low light even using the kit lens. By the ways, I found the kit lens very usable and I am able to get great shots with it. I plan to buy the 50 mm f1.8 prime lens in the near future and I am sure it will give me added ability combined with the T3. With regard to ISO, some of my shots at concerts with low and odd lighting have turned out excellent even using an ISO of 6400. Other shots, taken at this same ISO, have had camera noise that diminished them, but they were still usable. Some other cameras have the ability to shoot at higher ISOs and this would be useful, but not really necessary other than in really extreme low light situations.Many DSLRs shoot a larger number than the 12.2 MP the T3 has. More MP is needed only if you want to produce a print that is truly huge or do very severe cropping. Otherwise, 12.2 MP can make an up to 20 X 30 inch print that is excellent. More MP do not make a better picture other than the instances above. They do, however, take up more hard drive space. I can crop a T3 exposure in a severe manner and still have a good 8 X 10" print.I have taken shots outside when the temperature was below zero, and the camera functioned fine. It could take it as long as I could take it. Using the AEB setting (auto bracketing) I can take 3 different exposures of up to two stops apart in an instant. This is really useful for HDR photography.The T3 is easy to learn even if you don't have an extensive background in ISO, F-stop, and shutter speeds. The best way to learn with any camera is to take many, many shots. If some important shot is coming up, take a couple hundred shots with the T3, to get to know it a little, and you will do well. I've read some reviews that didn't think the T3 took good pictures. It is the photographers fault, not the camera. You have to learn to use enough shutter speed, combined with the right ISO and aperture, and then you can get nearly perfect pictures every time. This camera will help you with that but it still takes practice and a little skill to get it right. Even being an experienced user of an SLR, I still makes mistakes and am continuing to learn. Sometimes I make really dumb mistakes but even making mistakes makes you a better photographer.I have only taken maybe 3 videos with this camera. I didn't buy it to be a video camera. The videos I did take were adequate, not exceptional, and the sound quality was ok but not excellent. Get a good and large capacity sd card to use with the camera. The camera needs a good sd card to do all it can do. The first SD I purchased really didn't cut the mustard because it couldn't keep up with the camera on rapid shots. If you want excellent pictures shoot a large, fine jpeg or RAW or combine the two. Then the large SD card will pay for itself.While I plan to buy extra batteries, this camera can shot hundreds of shots on a single charge. It has a superb battery life.If you purchase a T3, I'll probably see your photos on Flickr. I like to look at the photos taken witha T3. Good luck and good shooting.

Reviews.Title: Nice one!
Reviews.Author: TM
Reviews.Content: I bought it for our honeymoon. I found it great and have nothing to complain about it! I strongly recommend it for beginners like me :)

Reviews.Title: Good dlsr starter camera
Reviews.Author: Jeannie
Reviews.Content: I bought this because all the reviews were so good and I had been lusting after a DSLR for a few years. I've had it for a few months and I'm still learning all of the features. It's confusing to me because it's my first dslr. I'm also taking a photo. class with it and learning how to edit pictures in photoshop and cs6 using RAW which has been great. The speed with which I'm learning the camera, photo techniques and editing is upped thanks to a knowledgable teacher.The shots are clear and beautiful. The camera isn't too heavy but feels sturdy enough. The lens is easy enough to remove.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic!
Reviews.Author: Me
Reviews.Content: I have never been more pleased.  I had a great camera which was stolen.  I wanted a Pentax but can't afford it. So I checked this one out and I am so glad I made the choice!

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera!
Reviews.Author: Mac_user
Reviews.Content: The canon T3 is the best camera in my option for the price. It has everything. 720p HD video, Changeable lens, and the 12.2 MP. I got mine after christmas so I got the camera, a 75-300mm lens for 9 dollars, free camera bag and the lens it comes with. I've had the Camera for a few months and I really like it. I'm a beginner photographer so I needed something better then a point and shoot but not a $800 dollar camera like the t4i. So if your looking for a great DSLR without breaking the bank this is the camera for you!

Reviews.Title: A great camera
Reviews.Author: H. D. Sanders Jr.
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera as an upgrade to my older cannon point and shoot.  It is an amazing and noticeable change. I didn't know what to expect after reading all of the reviews here on Amazon as well as on various other websites, but i'm very glad I purchased it.I have young children and the shots I'm getting are amazing.  I couldn't ask for more.  I assume the very technical and slightly negative reviews are from those people who should have purchased a higher end camera in the $1,000.00 range.  If you're a novice or a beginner I can assure you that this camera will be all you need.I caught this camera on sale and had it bundled with a backpack, a memory card and a nice long distance lens for just under 420.00.  There are deals to be had here on Amazon on this camera.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Entry-Level DSLR
Reviews.Author: mcan
Reviews.Content: I have had my T3 for a couple days and I have figured it out very easily. I am fifteen and I wanted to upgrade from a point-and-shoot to a DSLR. This is a perfect DSLR for a beginner. It has amazing quality pictures in different types of situations from low-light settings to high speed photography. I really recommend this camera. I haven't found any cons about it yet. Also, the price is outstanding for a great DSLR! The lens kit (18-55mm) is a perfect starting lens.

Reviews.Title: Great if you're not a bells-and-whistles type of person.
Reviews.Author: KayGirl
Reviews.Content: I love this camera! I had been looking at the T2i or T3i for a while, but couldn't afford them. It took a while to even save up enough (thanks to generous gifts from several family members and friends) to even afford this one. But once I got it, I realized that I love it! I use the different settings for monotone, cooler or warmer, etc., and when the auto settings aren't working well, I manually adjust the shutter speed and aperture. But I use the viewfinder more than the screen anyway, and I've realized that I really didn't need all the extra bells and whistles of the -i cameras. This one works great!

Reviews.Title: Canon Rebel T3
Reviews.Author: Mandi
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!  I have had this for a few months now and couldn't be happier.  I wanted a dslr just for fun beginning photography for fun and for capturing clear shots of my speedy little boy.  I was so pleased to find the Canon Rebel T3 for such a great price.  It takes great photos and I have had a lot of fun figuring out all of the features and learning how to capture those great shots.  Part of me wishes I would have sprung for the T3i, but I think this is a great beginning dslr and I have taken so many shots that I am so happy with.

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera
Reviews.Author: norman wann
Reviews.Content: I really like this camera. It has lots of features and is fairly easy to operate right out of the box. This is my first DLSR camera and am enjoying it very much. If you are looking for a camera for a beginner i would highly recommend this one.

Reviews.Title: A Camera for the Common Man
Reviews.Author: litchick
Reviews.Content: I am a new parent and my husband and I spent several months discussing whether or not we should invest in a new camera, one with better capabilities than my old Kodak digital. After a lot of research, we decided this Canon was the best bang for our buck. It does have more few more features than we need, but not too many, which is excellent as my husband and I are not photographers by any means. This camera is very easy to handle. The instruction book is really clear and concise, making the set up very smooth. Once you've got the lens in the right place and you've programmed the time and date, the camera pretty much takes care of the rest. The quality of the photos is just amazing and it was the perfect purchase for a set of parents whose infant will move by the time the auto-focus of a regular digital camera can take the photo. The only thing I would recommend you buy in addition to this camera is a pack of lens cloths. Sometimes dust and the occasional drop of water can get on the lens, which will show up on your picture and you can't use paper towels or facial tissue to wipe it clean. Although we have not tried shooting at night or a sporting event yet, overall, I have to say I love this camera and can't think of a better investment for my family.

Reviews.Title: Great product
Reviews.Author: buster324
Reviews.Content: All of my past cameras were point and shoot but I wanted a camera that took a better picture.  This is a great transitional camera if you're not familiar and not a professional.  The user book is easy to read and follow.  Pictures are beautiful.  Light weight and not as much of a burden as I thought it would be to carry around.  I read many other reviews from people that sounded like they knew what they were talking about, which really helped.  But this is a post for those that aren't photography/camera savvy but just want a great picture.  I highly recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Awesome for beginners
Reviews.Author: Calvin Hodgson
Reviews.Content: Very versatile DSLR camera for those who want to try out something different then point and shoot. Before this I mainly used my camera on my phone. Took alright pictures but they always turned out with poor color contrast. With this camera I get speed and very vivid colors. The built in histograms are great to meter if my shot is under or overexposed.Going through the menus is relatively easy. Loved the addition to make your own custom menu with options that I need on the fly. Very sturdy construction but it is made out of plastic because it is a lower end camera unlike the magnesium alloy counterparts. Rubberized grip should be on this camera but haven't had any worries about it falling out of my hands.Don't be overwhelmed about all the buttons on this camera. They're pretty simple to learn and you'll come to realize there usefulness.

Reviews.Title: I'm in love with this camera~!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This camera's been EXCELLENT! I'm not super pro at photography, but you would never know by the pictures! As a beginner, the camera was not difficult to figure out. (The internet was very helpful along with the manual) The picture quality is WONDERFUL. I have owned it for about a week now and have taken it everywhere. I've heard complaints about the battery, however, I've found the battery to last quite a while. (Takes about 700 shots per battery, good enough for me.) It is totally worth the money and I would recommend it in a heartbeat! :)

Reviews.Title: Solid built, Excellent image quality, Unbeatable price!
Reviews.Author: Atif Hassan
Reviews.Content: + Image quality is excellent, have only taken around 30 or so shots yet for portrait, macro, day and night.+ Excellent build quality, have no issues whatsoever with not having the rubber grip..this ones just fine.+ Unbelievable price...just recently S95 was $400!, i got it from dell.ca for $529 with body, lens, sd card and bag.+ All reviews i have researched claim its the best n most suitable entry level dslr for point n shoot crowd ie me.- Would love to have the movable lcd and other specs but those are costlier.- Have no idea about dslr or photography..but would have gotten 7D or T3i if i could afford it.= As we all have slim point & shoots anyways..for next step up into dslr territory, can't beat the reputation & price, recommned buy!

Reviews.Title: Awesome for beginners!
Reviews.Author: Paul B. "G33K"
Reviews.Content: I got this camera about a week ago and love it.  It's not Canon's flashiest, but it's an awesome starting point to jump into DSLRs.  The stock lens is alright, but I already have a list of others to buy next, and the body takes both EF and EF-S lenses.  The microphone is a bit weak, but who buys a DSLR to use strictly as a video camera?  If you're on the fence and want to get your feet wet in photography, don't hesitate to buy this little guy.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: nyamo
Reviews.Content: Absolutely love this camera! Got this camera because just had a baby and wanted to be able to take quality pictures. Takes the most beautiful pictures and the settings are easy to use. Saw other reviews listed a complaint about how cheap and plasticky the camera is, but I found it made the camera more lightweight and easier to handle. Completely recommed this camera.

Reviews.Title: AMAZING!
Reviews.Author: melissaxxv
Reviews.Content: I have never used a DSLR before and have NO IDEA what I'm doing but I have a few photographer friends that said this is their dream camera and I got it and amazingly enough theres an automatic setting for everything! The pictures are amazing! The BEST camera for beginners! And I assume for professionals also since all my friends that do photography for a living want this!

Reviews.Title: Love picture quality but don't expect fast picture taking.
Reviews.Author: Martha Millard
Reviews.Content: I may not know all of the functions yet, but I love the picture quality that this camera has. My fifteen year old daughter took it out in the snow and captured some studio quality shots of her older sister. It took some adjusting indoors to get pictures of inside sporting events. The shutter is not quick to respond in the auto position when indoors. The camera takes and incredibly long time trying to focus before it will snap a picture if it does at all. Using the camera in the av or tv mode while snapping inside pictures helped some. It takes nice pictures at a distance with the 200mm telephoto lens which I purchased separately, but that is a bit cumbersome for on the fly shots. I love the quality but haven't figured out all the settings that work best for quick action shots from a distance indoors. Even using the sports/action setting did not help. I also adjusted the ISO, but I will continue playing with it because I love the quality of the photos, and this is my first digital slr.

Reviews.Title: Excellent piece of work
Reviews.Author: Warren Neal
Reviews.Content: I wanted a fairly high quality DSLR that wouldn't clean out my bank account. I checked out two similarly priced cameras -- the Canon and a Nikon. Both have high name regonition, and I feel like the Nikon is probably a good camera; but, based on the Amazon reviews and the price, I chose the Canon - my first DSLR. I am delighted with the choice. It seems very high quality and well constructed, with a substantial set of useful features.
